Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I was just finishing up sweeping the salon floor when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was an email from a colleague at work—nothing urgent, just a note about next week’s project, but I knew the unspoken rule: respond promptly, even if it’s just to acknowledge receipt. I glanced at the clock. The bride-to-be and her bridesmaids were already at the door, fifteen minutes early, their faces tight with nerves. As a hairdresser, I’m expected to greet clients warmly, put them at ease, and set the tone for their big day. But my mind was split. If I paused to send a quick reply, I’d leave the bridal party waiting, possibly making their anxiety worse. If I greeted them right away, I’d risk my colleague thinking I was ignoring work messages. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, phone in hand, caught between two worlds—each expecting me to be fully present, neither willing to wait.
